title: 105_hr4737
content: The Act titled "Treatment of Children's Deformities Act of 1998" covers benefits for minor children's congenital or developmental deformities or disorders under group health plans. It amends the Public Health Service Act to establish standards for these benefits. The Act "Treatment of Children's Deformities Act of 1998" requires group health plans to cover outpatient and inpatient diagnosis and treatment of minor children's congenital or developmental deformities, diseases, or injuries up to 21 years of age. Coverage must include pre-authorization for surgical treatment deemed medically necessary by the treating physician to approximate a normal appearance. The term "treatment" in the Act includes reconstructive surgical procedures for abnormal structures caused by various factors, excluding cosmetic surgery for normal structures. Cosmetic surgery is a type of surgery that reshapes normal body structures to enhance appearance or self-esteem. Group health plans must comply with certain notice requirements related to this type of surgery. Amendments have been made to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 to include sections 2704 and 2706. Standards for benefits related to minor child's congenital or developmental deformity or disorder are outlined in SEC. 713. Requirements for reconstructive surgery for minor children include coverage for diagnosis and treatment of congenital or developmental deformities, subject to pre-authorization. Treatment must be deemed medically necessary by the treating physician to approximate a normal appearance. Reconstructive surgical procedures are included in the term "treatment" for abnormal body structures caused by various factors, excluding cosmetic surgery for normal structures. Cosmetic surgery is performed to reshape normal body structures for aesthetic purposes or to boost self-esteem. The requirements for notice under a group health plan regarding such procedures are outlined in specific sections of the Act. The Act (29 U.S.C. 1191a(a)) is amended to include section 713. The table of contents is updated to reflect this change. Section 713 of the Act amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish standards for benefits related to a minor child's congenital or developmental deformity or disorder. This amendment is reflected in the updated table of contents. "SEC. 9813. STANDARDS RELATING TO BENEFITS FOR MINOR CHILD'S CONGENITAL OR DEVELOPMENTAL DEFORMITY OR DISORDER." Requirements for Reconstructive Surgery include coverage for diagnosis and treatment of a minor child's congenital or developmental deformity, subject to pre-authorization. Treatment must be deemed medically necessary by the treating physician to approximate a normal appearance. The term "treatment" in this section includes reconstructive surgical procedures for abnormal structures caused by various factors, excluding cosmetic surgery for normal structures. Cosmetic surgery is a type of surgery that reshapes normal body structures to enhance appearance or self-esteem. Individual health insurance regulations are amended to exclude coverage for cosmetic surgery on normal structures. Standards for benefits related to minor child's congenital or developmental deformity or disorder are outlined in SEC. 2752. Requirements for reconstructive surgery for minor children include coverage for outpatient and inpatient diagnosis and treatment of congenital or developmental deformities, subject to pre-authorization. Treatment must be deemed medically necessary by the treating physician to approximate a normal appearance. Reconstructive surgical procedures are covered for abnormal structures caused by various factors, including congenital defects, trauma, or disease. This includes procedures to improve function or appearance, but not cosmetic surgery for normal structures. Cosmetic surgery is performed to reshape normal body structures for aesthetic reasons. Health insurance issuers must comply with certain notice requirements. Amendments to the Act apply to group health plans and health insurance coverage from specific dates. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 is amended to apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market. Coordinated regulations now include provisions from the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, the Public Health Service Act, and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
